passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Frederick Grant Banting, a young Canadian orthopedic surgeon, was raised on a small Ontario farm. He initially enrolled at the University of Toronto’s Victoria College to study for the ministry, but in the fall of 1912 , he decided to transfer to U of T’s medical school, despite having no premedical preparation. Unfortunately, his medical studies were interrupted by World War I, and in 1915, Banting, along with other students, enlisted in the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps. However, they ultimately returned to the university to complete medical school at an accelerated pace, graduating in December of 1916 with medical degrees. Banting served as a medical officer in a Canadian hospital in England and was awarded the Military Cross by the British government for his valor and bravery during the Cambrai campaign. After returning to Toronto in March of 1919, he joined the staff at the Hospital for Sick Children and worked as a surgical resident. He then relocated to London, Ontario, where he opened a general surgical practice. During his time in London, he took up a part-time position in teaching anatomy and physiology at the University of Western Ontario (UWO), a local medical school.

(2). When Banting commenced his role at the University of Western Ontario in 1920, he was still largely unknown in the medical community. Although Banting worked as a lecturer in the university’s Department of Physiology, he was less interested in teaching and was more keen to conduct research as well as continue hands-on medical practice. Since Banting preferred lab work to spending time in the classroom, his time at UWO was brief; by 1921, he elected to take a leave of absence from his position in order to continue his research in Toronto, a decision which would help to facilitate his part in the eventual discovery of insulin. Unsurprisingly, Banting's role in the discovery of insulin eclipsed his academic career in the history books, but his tenure at UWO nonetheless played a critical role in shaping his future, as the time he spent teaching broadened his knowledge of medicine and physiology.

(3). On October 30, 1920, while preparing for a lecture on the pancreas , Banting came across an article by Moses Barron entitled, “The Relation of the Islets of Langerhans to Diabetes, With Special Reference to Cases of Pancreatic Lithiasis.” In a rare autopsy case, Barron observed that a pancreatic stone had formed and obstructed the main pancreatic duct, leading to the atrophy of all acinar cells, while most islet cells not only survived but also remained intact. Barron noted the similarities between the observations in this case and in experimental cases where pancreatic ducts were blocked by ligation.

(4). Thus, such evidence strengthened the belief that the pancreatic islets were significant in explaining diabetes . The challenge encountered by those who attempted to study the role of the Islets of Langerhans in diabetes was in separating the extract of the islets from the rest of the pancreatic exocrine tissue . Banting hypothesized that during the extraction of the whole pancreatic gland the active principle implicated in glucose regulation was perhaps destroyed by digestive enzymes in the acinar tissue of the pancreas. This, he suspected, led to the failure of those that attempted to study the Islets of Langerhans before him. Later, Banting would indeed succeed in overcoming this challenge.

(5). To appreciate why it was necessary to halt the exocrine capacity of the pancreatic gland to investigate glucose regulation, it is essential to recall the function and anatomy of the pancreas. The pancreas serves two functions: endocrine and exocrine. The pancreatic islets (Islets of Langerhans ) contain the hormone-producing endocrine cells, whereas the pancreatic acini ( acinar cells) serve an exocrine function i.e., producing digestive enzymes, which are released into the duodenum via pancreatic ducts. Duct ligation was thus necessary to cause the acini cells to atrophy, leaving behind only the cells from the islets of Langerhans, which could be further investigated.

(6). In Banting’s notebook, which is preserved in the archives of the Academy of Medicine in Toronto, he wrote: “Diabetus. Ligate pancreatic ducts of dog. Keep dogs alive till acini degenerate, leaving Islets. Try to isolate the internal secretion of these to relieve glycosuria.” By ligating the ducts and allowing the acinar cells to degenerate over time, Banting was hoping to isolate the internal secretion of the islet cells without the destructive action of pancreatic enzymes present in the external secretion of the acinar cells. It must be noted that Banting’s idea was not entirely new; several other investigators had attempted to prepare pancreatic extracts. The result of Banting’s tests was a temporary sugar-reducing effect adjoined by adverse side effects, such as fever and abscesses, primarily believed to be caused by impurities in the extract.

(7). Shortly after arriving in London, Ontario, Banting decided to present his ideas to John J. R. Macleod in November of 1920 upon the advice of F. R. Miller , a neurophysiologist whom Banting had assisted with experiments during his tenure/time as a teacher at UWO medical school. Macleod, a physiology professor, and the head of the physiology department at U of T, had great insight into carbohydrate metabolism, and would also be able to provide Banting with a research facility and resources to test his proposal. According to Macleod’s own research, he too held the position that there was an internal secretion of the pancreas that might never be isolated in a pancreatic extract. However, as Banting explained his ideas to Macleod, he was met with skepticism . Macleod, well-versed in the literature, explained that many notable scientists had attempted to isolate this hormone but had failed. Nevertheless, Banting persisted, and after meeting with Macleod two more times, the latter, at last, agreed to arrange laboratory space for Banting to conduct his experiments. Charles H. Best was assigned by Macleod to help Banting test his hypothesis.

(8). Banting and Best’s experimental work began in May of 1921, employing two sets of dogs. The pancreases were removed from the first set , making them diabetic; these dogs would later receive injections with the “isolated internal secretion of the islets cells” to test the success of their experimental techniques/procedures. In the other set of dogs , they ligated the pancreatic ducts to first halt the exocrine activity of the glands, and then harvest secretions from these to treat the diabetic set of dogs. After some initial setbacks, on July 30, Banting and Best noted improvements, albeit temporary, when they administered the sample to the experimentally induced diabetic dog. They repeated their experiments and documented frequent decreases in blood sugar levels in two more de-pancreatized dogs . They named this initial extract “ isletin ”.

(9). Although the duct ligation procedure was of great scientific interest, it was not possible to repeat such procedures on a large scale to produce enough for clinical use. Thus, a better method needed to be discovered.

(10). The duct ligation procedure could not be replicated on a larger scale for numerous reasons. The procedure was complex and time-consuming, involving intricate surgeries that would have been impractical and labor-intensive to perform on large numbers of dogs or other animals. The amount of insulin that could be extracted from a single animal was limited, making it difficult to produce enough for human use. Additionally, the yield of insulin was inconsistent, which made the method unreliable for large-scale production. Another drawback of the procedure was that it caused harm to the animals, meaning it raised significant ethical concerns. In the end, the necessity of performing challenging surgeries, and collecting enough secretions for large scale production, before extracting and purifying the hormones, made the procedure much too slow to feasibly deliver it to the public in large quantities. A better and more efficient system was needed if insulin was to be made readily available for all who required it.

Alcohol solved this problem since it evaporates at a much lower temperature than water. Banting and Best were eager to test if they could get a similar result from a fresh adult pancreas; not only were they able to achieve this, but they noted a drop in blood sugar from 0.460% to 0.180% in 3 hours. Thus, there was no need for a degenerated pancreas or a fetal pancreas, as they had initially believed. Rather, a whole pancreas extract with alcohol seemed to be the secret combination.

As more patients were treated at the Toronto General Hospital, similar favorable results emerged, and it began to make headlines, capturing the world’s attention. The discovery of insulin is arguably one of Canada’s biggest contributions to medical research, as it completely revolutionized the treatment of diabetes.

He then relocated to London, Ontario, where he opened a general surgical practice. During his time in London, he took up a part-time position in teaching anatomy and physiology at the University of Western Ontario (UWO), a local medical school.

(2). When Banting commenced his role at the University of Western Ontario in 1920, he was still largely unknown in the medical community. Unsurprisingly, Banting's role in the discovery of insulin eclipsed his academic career in the history books, but his tenure at UWO nonetheless played a critical role in shaping his future, as the time he spent teaching broadened his knowledge of medicine and physiology.

(3). (5). To appreciate why it was necessary to halt the exocrine capacity of the pancreatic gland to investigate glucose regulation, it is essential to recall the function and anatomy of the pancreas. The pancreas serves two functions: endocrine and exocrine. The pancreatic islets (Islets of Langerhans ) contain the hormone-producing endocrine cells, whereas the pancreatic acini ( acinar cells) serve an exocrine function i.e., producing digestive enzymes, which are released into the duodenum via pancreatic ducts. (2). When Banting commenced his role at the University of Western Ontario in 1920, he was still largely unknown in the medical community. Although Banting worked as a lecturer in the university’s Department of Physiology, he was less interested in teaching and was more keen to conduct research as well as continue hands-on medical practice. passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Frederick Grant Banting, a young Canadian orthopedic surgeon, was raised on a small Ontario farm. He initially enrolled at the University of Toronto’s Victoria College to study for the ministry, but in the fall of 1912 , he decided to transfer to U of T’s medical school, despite having no premedical preparation. Unfortunately, his medical studies were interrupted by World War I, and in 1915, Banting, along with other students, enlisted in the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps. However, they ultimately returned to the university to complete medical school at an accelerated pace, graduating in December of 1916 with medical degrees. Banting served as a medical officer in a Canadian hospital in England and was awarded the Military Cross by the British government for his valor and bravery during the Cambrai campaign. After returning to Toronto in March of 1919, he joined the staff at the Hospital for Sick Children and worked as a surgical resident. He then relocated to London, Ontario, where he opened a general surgical practice. During his time in London, he took up a part-time position in teaching anatomy and physiology at the University of Western Ontario (UWO), a local medical school.

(2). When Banting commenced his role at the University of Western Ontario in 1920, he was still largely unknown in the medical community. Although Banting worked as a lecturer in the university’s Department of Physiology, he was less interested in teaching and was more keen to conduct research as well as continue hands-on medical practice. Since Banting preferred lab work to spending time in the classroom, his time at UWO was brief; by 1921, he elected to take a leave of absence from his position in order to continue his research in Toronto, a decision which would help to facilitate his part in the eventual discovery of insulin. Unsurprisingly, Banting's role in the discovery of insulin eclipsed his academic career in the history books, but his tenure at UWO nonetheless played a critical role in shaping his future, as the time he spent teaching broadened his knowledge of medicine and physiology.

(3). On October 30, 1920, while preparing for a lecture on the pancreas , Banting came across an article by Moses Barron entitled, “The Relation of the Islets of Langerhans to Diabetes, With Special Reference to Cases of Pancreatic Lithiasis.” In a rare autopsy case, Barron observed that a pancreatic stone had formed and obstructed the main pancreatic duct, leading to the atrophy of all acinar cells, while most islet cells not only survived but also remained intact. Barron noted the similarities between the observations in this case and in experimental cases where pancreatic ducts were blocked by ligation.

(4). Thus, such evidence strengthened the belief that the pancreatic islets were significant in explaining diabetes . The challenge encountered by those who attempted to study the role of the Islets of Langerhans in diabetes was in separating the extract of the islets from the rest of the pancreatic exocrine tissue . Banting hypothesized that during the extraction of the whole pancreatic gland the active principle implicated in glucose regulation was perhaps destroyed by digestive enzymes in the acinar tissue of the pancreas. This, he suspected, led to the failure of those that attempted to study the Islets of Langerhans before him. Later, Banting would indeed succeed in overcoming this challenge.

(5). To appreciate why it was necessary to halt the exocrine capacity of the pancreatic gland to investigate glucose regulation, it is essential to recall the function and anatomy of the pancreas. The pancreas serves two functions: endocrine and exocrine. The pancreatic islets (Islets of Langerhans ) contain the hormone-producing endocrine cells, whereas the pancreatic acini ( acinar cells) serve an exocrine function i.e., producing digestive enzymes, which are released into the duodenum via pancreatic ducts. Duct ligation was thus necessary to cause the acini cells to atrophy, leaving behind only the cells from the islets of Langerhans, which could be further investigated.

(6). In Banting’s notebook, which is preserved in the archives of the Academy of Medicine in Toronto, he wrote: “Diabetus. Ligate pancreatic ducts of dog. Keep dogs alive till acini degenerate, leaving Islets. Try to isolate the internal secretion of these to relieve glycosuria.” By ligating the ducts and allowing the acinar cells to degenerate over time, Banting was hoping to isolate the internal secretion of the islet cells without the destructive action of pancreatic enzymes present in the external secretion of the acinar cells. It must be noted that Banting’s idea was not entirely new; several other investigators had attempted to prepare pancreatic extracts. The result of Banting’s tests was a temporary sugar-reducing effect adjoined by adverse side effects, such as fever and abscesses, primarily believed to be caused by impurities in the extract.

(7). Shortly after arriving in London, Ontario, Banting decided to present his ideas to John J. R. Macleod in November of 1920 upon the advice of F. R. Miller , a neurophysiologist whom Banting had assisted with experiments during his tenure/time as a teacher at UWO medical school. Macleod, a physiology professor, and the head of the physiology department at U of T, had great insight into carbohydrate metabolism, and would also be able to provide Banting with a research facility and resources to test his proposal. According to Macleod’s own research, he too held the position that there was an internal secretion of the pancreas that might never be isolated in a pancreatic extract. However, as Banting explained his ideas to Macleod, he was met with skepticism . Macleod, well-versed in the literature, explained that many notable scientists had attempted to isolate this hormone but had failed. Nevertheless, Banting persisted, and after meeting with Macleod two more times, the latter, at last, agreed to arrange laboratory space for Banting to conduct his experiments. Charles H. Best was assigned by Macleod to help Banting test his hypothesis.

(8). Banting and Best’s experimental work began in May of 1921, employing two sets of dogs. The pancreases were removed from the first set , making them diabetic; these dogs would later receive injections with the “isolated internal secretion of the islets cells” to test the success of their experimental techniques/procedures. In the other set of dogs , they ligated the pancreatic ducts to first halt the exocrine activity of the glands, and then harvest secretions from these to treat the diabetic set of dogs. After some initial setbacks, on July 30, Banting and Best noted improvements, albeit temporary, when they administered the sample to the experimentally induced diabetic dog. They repeated their experiments and documented frequent decreases in blood sugar levels in two more de-pancreatized dogs . They named this initial extract “ isletin ”.

(9). Although the duct ligation procedure was of great scientific interest, it was not possible to repeat such procedures on a large scale to produce enough for clinical use. Thus, a better method needed to be discovered.

(10). The duct ligation procedure could not be replicated on a larger scale for numerous reasons. The procedure was complex and time-consuming, involving intricate surgeries that would have been impractical and labor-intensive to perform on large numbers of dogs or other animals. The amount of insulin that could be extracted from a single animal was limited, making it difficult to produce enough for human use. Additionally, the yield of insulin was inconsistent, which made the method unreliable for large-scale production. Another drawback of the procedure was that it caused harm to the animals, meaning it raised significant ethical concerns. In the end, the necessity of performing challenging surgeries, and collecting enough secretions for large scale production, before extracting and purifying the hormones, made the procedure much too slow to feasibly deliver it to the public in large quantities. A better and more efficient system was needed if insulin was to be made readily available for all who required it.

(11). In early December 1921, Banting and Best decided to use alcohol in the preparation of a fetal calf extract. The challenge faced with an aqueous saline extract was that, attempting to concentrate the extract by boiling off the water, this also seemed to destroy the much sought-after active principle. Alcohol solved this problem since it evaporates at a much lower temperature than water. Banting and Best were eager to test if they could get a similar result from a fresh adult pancreas; not only were they able to achieve this, but they noted a drop in blood sugar from 0.460% to 0.180% in 3 hours. Thus, there was no need for a degenerated pancreas or a fetal pancreas, as they had initially believed. Rather, a whole pancreas extract with alcohol seemed to be the secret combination.

(12). Macleod, recognizing the breakthrough made by Banting and Best, decided to join in and included J. B. Collip in the team. Collip, an experienced biochemist, was assigned the task of purification. Collip’s purification work was monumental, and, in the winter of 1922, a young 14-year-old diabetic boy was treated with a purified extract made by Collip. The boy’s blood sugar decreased dramatically from 0.520% to 0.120% in the span of a day and his glucose excretion (in urine) dropped from 71.1 g to 8.7 g. The boy also looked brighter, felt better, and had become more active. This incident was noted as the first distinctly successful clinical test on a human diabetic patient who had been injected with the internal secretion of the pancreas. As more patients were treated at the Toronto General Hospital, similar favorable results emerged, and it began to make headlines, capturing the world’s attention. The discovery of insulin is arguably one of Canada’s biggest contributions to medical research, as it completely revolutionized the treatment of diabetes.
